description.narrative:
The China Dialogue Trust promotes communication across barriers of language and culture on environment and climate change to inform, educate and build a global consensus for equitable and constructive solutions to urgent problems. We do this through the production, publication and dissemination of news and analysis.
The China Dialogue Trust disseminates high-quality information and promotes communication on the environment and climate change globally. The China Dialogue Trust aim to inform and contribute to building equitable and constructive solutions to global environmental problems. The China Dialogue Trust believe that this requires a common purpose across political, ideological and cultural boundaries. The China Dialogue Trust foster that common purpose by providing our readers with independent and accurate information that may otherwise be difficult to access, and by facilitating tolerant and constructive dialogue. China Dialogue Trust also manages its sister projects like -The Third Pole, India Climate Dialogue, Chinadialogue.oceanand Dialogo Chino.
The Third Pole supports in-depth, non-partisan and Original coverage of all aspects of water in the counties ofthe Himalayan and Lancang-Mekong basin, to stimulate informed debate and to promote cooperation on transboundary river management. Over the years the pioneering online forum www.thirdpole.net has established a reputation as the source of accessible high quality and balanced material on transboundary water in the Himalayan and Lancang-Mekong
This complies with Oxfam Goals

participating-org.narrative:
The China Dialogue Trust promotes communication across barriers of language and culture on environment and climate change to inform, educate and build a global consensus for equitable and constructive solutions to urgent problems. We do this through the production, publication and dissemination of news and analysis
The China Dialogue Trust disseminates high-quality information and promotes communication on the environment and climate change globally. The China Dialogue Trust aim to inform and contribute to building equitable and constructive solutions to global environmental problems. The China Dialogue Trust believe that this requires a common purpose across political, ideological and cultural boundaries. The China Dialogue Trust foster that common purpose by providing our readers with independent and accurate information that may otherwise be difficult to access, and by facilitating tolerant and constructive dialogue.
China Dialogue Trust also manages its sister projects like -The Third Pole, India Climate Dialogue, Chinadialogue.oceanand Dialogo Chino.
The Third Pole supports in-depth, non-partisan and Original coverage of all aspects of water in the counties ofthe Himalayan and Lancang-Mekong basin, to stimulate informed debate and to promote cooperation on transboundary river management. Over the years the pioneering online forum www.thirdpole.net has established a reputation as the source of accessible high quality and balanced material on transboundary water in the Himalayan and Lancang-Mekong The Sustainable Development Investment Portfolio (SDIP) of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), Government of Australia, has been engaged in a number of projects that seek to ameliorate this situation in various ways. But in this sphere, there is a lack of evidence-based media reporting, while much of the reporting that exists is biased or inaccurate or lacks regional perspective. What is needed is open research- and evidence-based communication through the media, that brings the problems and the solutions to the attention of policymakers and other stakeholders everywhere. Many of the solutions have applicability beyond national boundaries, but remain largely unknown if there is no commonand credible communication platform. For adecade, The Third Pole (TTP) has been the benchmark communication platform for sustainable development of transboundary river basins in South Asia. It has done this through consistent reportage of both problems and solutions in these basins, seen throughthe lens of ecosystems rather than political boundaries. This has had positive fallout on regional cooperation for sustainable development at all levels, from federal governments to village councils and non-profit groups. For example, TTP has supported increased dialogue between countries on the benefits of federal-level cooperation in the Brahmaputra, Ganga, Koshi and Indus basins. TTP has also supported increased transboundary cooperation between local women#s groups in the Koshi basin. Its reportage on the positive impacts of regional cooperation at all levels has been particularly effective; the repeated focus on the effects of climate change has brought this issue centre stage in national plans. Its persistent coverage of the special vulnerabilitiesofwomen has brought focus to the need for gender sensitive planning. Apart from its own coverage, TTP has been organising mediatraining workshops and providing media fellowships to enable journalists to get a better and more in-depth understanding of ecological, hydrological, economic, social, cultural and political issues in the transboundary river basins of South Asia. These workshops and fellowships have been organised in partnership with the Department for International Development (DfID), Governmentof UK; the German development agency GiZ; the Swiss development agency SDC; the Department of Science and Technology (DST), Government of India; the South Asia Water Initiative (SAWI) of the World Bank; The Asia Foundation; the Network for Social Change (N4SC); the Climate Justice Resilience Fund; the International Water Management Institute; and the Internews# Earth Journalism Network, among others. Over 600 journalists in Bangladesh, Bhutan, China, India, Nepal and Pakistan have been trained in these workshops and been selected for fellowships in the last decade, and they have produced over 2,000 media reports showing an improved understanding of the urgent need for sustainable development in transboundary river basins and the need for improved regional collaboration for this purpose. The Third Pole is a project of the UK based charity China Dialogue Trust, and has a small core staff in New Delhi, Kathmandu, Karachi, Dhaka, Beijing and London. We leverage our influence through a wider network of over 150 leading water experts, NGOs, media organisations, research institutions and journalists across Asia and elsewhere. Many of these experts join our media training workshops as resource persons.
Name of the company is China Dialogue Trust Registered under company acts 1985 <(>&<)> 2006, Company limited by guarantee and not having a share capital. Company No 6477262
Registered under charities number 1125378

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security

description.narrative: Communities innovate and implement locally owned solutions for climate adaptation and resilience, with recognition of the specific needs and aspirations of women, men and youth.
CBOs and NGO's resourced to innovate and implement locally owned solutions, recognizing specific needs and aspirations of women, men and youth

CBOs, producer organisations, NGO and other civil society actors with strengthened capacities to advocate and to increase people's voice in decisions on policies regarding agriculture production systems, land scape management and market systems
local communities, CBOs and small holder organisations that promote innovative locally owned solutions, recognizing and promoting gender equality and women and youth leadership
Public institutions are improving their policy and practices in pro of climate adaptation, resilience and food security

cases where governments improved their policy and/or regulations regarding support for climate adaptation, resilience and food security for small scale food producers (including agro-ecology, just land and NNRR governance ).

cases where governments increased their ODA or national budgets for climate adaptation, resilience and food security for small scale food producers (this relates to agro-ecology, just land and NNRR governance )
cases where participatory approaches to community resilience being upscaled and institutionalized, contributing to e.g. NDC, NAPs and NBSAPs
